div.l: And knewe the Estrees / bet than did this Iohn
And by the walle a staffe she founde a noon
And sawe a lytel slymeryng of a lyght
For at an hoole in shoon the mone bright
And by that lyght / she sawe hem bothe two
But sykyrly she nyst / whoo was whoo
But as she sawe / a white thyng in hire Iye
And whan she gan this white thyng espye
She wende the Clerke / had wered volupere
And with the staffe / she drough here nere
And wende han hitte / this Aleyn atte fulle
And smote the Miller / on the pilled skulle
That doun he goyth / and cryed harrow I dye
Thies Clerkes bet hym wele and lete hym lye
And ordeyned hem / and tooke hors a noon
And eke her mele / and on her wey they goon
And at the Mille / yet they toke hire cake
Of halfe a busshel floure / full wele YIIY bake
Thus is this proude Millere / wele y bete
And hath loste the gryndyng / of the whete
And paied for the soper eủerydele
Of Aleyn and of Iohn / that bet hym wele
Hys wyfe is swyfed / and his doughter als
Lo suche it is a Myller to be fals
And therfore this proủerbe is seide full soth
Hym dar not wene wele / that evel dooth
A gylour shal hym selfe / begiled be
And god that sitteth hie in mageste
Saue all this compaignye grete and smale
Thus haue I quyte the Millere in my tale
Here be gynnyth the ꝓprologe of the coke of londoıı̄un
The Cook of london / while the Reve spakespakespak
For Ioy hym thought / he clawed hym on the bak
A ha quod he / for cristes passion
This Miller hadde a sharpe conclusion
